critique: This document pertains to the designation of an acting judge for the U.S. District Court of Puerto Rico in 1934. Given the limited scope and nature of the document, assessing its position on the traditional left-right political spectrum is difficult; it does not directly address social welfare, cultural values, or the general role of government. Similarly, the document does not directly relate to immigration, border enforcement, or visa policies. The document could be seen as an expansion of executive power, as it is an executive designation. The document touches on federalism, as it concerns the relationship between the U.S. government and Puerto Rico. The document does not directly address national security or civil liberties. The document does not directly address economic regulation. The document has no implications for social inclusion.
